text.2_Daf, 0_Line, 1_Comment: As we will explain later on, "and these three are in female form." And the Gemara will ask why it's taught in feminine form.
text.2_Daf, 0_Line, 2_Comment: Our printing: And she "acquires" herself in two ways
text.2_Daf, 0_Line, 3_Comment: To be within her rights to marry another
text.2_Daf, 0_Line, 4_Comment: The Braisa explains in the Gemara (5b), [acquisition with money:] give her money or money-equivalent and say to her, "behold you are betrothed to me." Document: write it for her on paper, even though the paper is not worth a prutah, [say,] "behold you are betrothed to me." Through intercourse: come upon her and say "betroth me with this intercourse." All of this is learned from the [written] Torah.
text.2_Daf, 0_Line, 5_Comment: Beit Shammai's reasoning is explained in the Gemara (11a)
text.2_Daf, 0_Line, 7_Comment: of silver and its value is eight prutas.
text.2_Daf, 1_Line, 1_Comment: To be his wife for all matters, for if he came to divorce her afterward, she does not need from him halitza rather a bill of divorce [get]. But money or a document do not have the effect of betrothing her from the Torah, rather from the Sages as they instituted an order, as they say in Yevamot. But (money or a document) do not finalize the betrothal to allow him to inherit from her or become impure for her and do not exempt from halitza, rather they make her forbidden to the other brothers.
text.2_Daf, 2_Line, 0_Comment: 1 . And what's the difference there--In the second chapter (41a) where it says "the man betroths himself or with his agent," let it say here: the woman becomes betrothed
text.2_Daf, 2_Line, 1_Comment: 2. Because it needs to teach money--that with [money] we aquire, and we said previous (4b) "from where do we know that we can acquire with money," and we explain that we learn "take" "take" from the Field of Efron that we consider it an acquisition. Therefore we learn here that [money] can acquire.
text.4_Daf, 3_Line, 0_Comment: 1. What is the number in the beginning coming to exclude?- three ways.
text.4_Daf, 3_Line, 1_Comment: 2.What is the number in the end coming to exclude?- And she acquires herself back in two ways.
text.4_Daf, 4_Line, 0_Comment: To exclude the marriage canopy - If her father delivered her to the marriage canopy for the purpose of kiddushin, she is not thereby betrothed.
text.5_Daf, 0_Line, 0_Comment: It does not acquire her soul - it is a disgrace to her; therefore the method of chalifin is abolished for her when doing kiddushin. And even with a vessel whose worth is greater than that of a pruta, if you bring it to her with the language of chalifin [it does not acquire her soul] until he brings her according to the laws with the language of acquisition or buying or kiddushin.
text.6_Daf, 12_Line, 3_Comment: For it has not yet reached six years
text.14_Daf, 10_Line, 0_Comment: "Who was a great man" - and he didn't go out with his head uncovered.
text.17_Daf, 4_Line, 1_Comment: Documents of apportionment-These are the conditions between the parties, and money which they pledge one to another
text.42_Daf, 1_Line, 0_Comment: You have the ability to marry her - kiddushin-marriage is valid with although he is a heathen for she does not convert willingly.
text.57_Daf, 10_Line, 0_Comment: If his son is diligent and the father sees that he will be more successful than he, and he does not have enough assets that both of them could study - his son should study and he should toil after provisions and take care of him.
text.57_Daf, 11_Line, 0_Comment: The house of the rabbis: The study hall was far from the settlement.
text.57_Daf, 11_Line, 1_Comment: No one should give him lodging to Rav Acha. So perforce he will have to lodge in the study hall. And because of his saintliness, a miracle will happen for him and he will kill the demon.
text.57_Daf, 12_Line, 2_Comment: Like a serpent with seven heads: As it had seven skulls.
text.57_Daf, 12_Line, 3_Comment: Every bow that he bowed - Rav Acha, he was praying about that demon - one head fell off.
text.59_Daf, 14_Line, 0_Comment: That a father is required to perform for his son: For example, to circumcise him and to redeem him. And this is what is implied in our mishnah - "all mitzvot" that "a father" is commanded with regard to" the acts" of "the son."
text.59_Daf, 15_Line, 0_Comment: That is incumbent upon the son: For example, honor and reverence.
text.59_Daf, 16_Line, 0_Comment: Power: He is able, since there is no one to protest against him.
text.59_Daf, 16_Line, 2_Comment: [If she] is divorced: From her husband. Then she is like one of her [unmarried] sisters regarding the mitzvah of honor.
text.59_Daf, 19_Line, 0_Comment: But with regard to striking, it is certainly not possible: To compare it, since there is no striking towards the Above.
text.59_Daf, 20_Line, 0_Comment: And so is it logical: That [the parents] be compared [to God] for honor and reverence upon the child; as behold they also partners with the Omnipresent in [creating] him.
text.59_Daf, 20_Line, 1_Comment: There are three partners: It is explained in a baraita in Tractate Niddah (31a): The man emits the white in him. The woman emits the red in him. And the Holy One, Blessed be He, blows into him, a soul, eyesight, hearing of the ear and speech.
text.60_Daf, 0_Line, 0_Comment: As she persuades him (meshadalto): She entices him; as we translate (Onkelos on Exodus 22:15), "And if a man entices," as Arei yeshadal.
text.60_Daf, 1_Line, 0_Comment: "And the earth is My footstool": So one who transgresses in private is saying the Omnipresent is not here. Hence he is hidden, saying, "He does not know." It comes out that it is as though he is pushing away His feet and shortening Him, saying, "[He is] not here."
text.60_Daf, 2_Line, 0_Comment: "The entire world is full": It implies that He extends and descends below. So one who stands with an upright posture appears as [if he] is pushing [God] away.
text.60_Daf, 3_Line, 0_Comment: He said this to him: Rabbi Yehoshua answered him in the [same] way that Rabbi Eliezer answered him.
text.60_Daf, 4_Line, 0_Comment: [If] she is divorced: Such that my mother is not obligated to honor my father. [If so], what is [the law]?
text.60_Daf, 4_Line, 1_Comment: From your eyelashes: [These are] the hairs in the rows of eyelids. It is evident that you were orphaned, so your eyelashes fell out due to the crying. As it as we say [in Sanhedrin] (104b), "And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel heard her voice and cried with her until his eyelashes fell out.
text.60_Daf, 4_Line, 2_Comment: That you are the son of a widow And that you do not need [my answer] in practice. Rather you have come to learn, and I tell you that the honor of both of them is the same upon you.
text.60_Daf, 4_Line, 3_Comment: Pour water for them into a pitcher and squawk: Crow to them, as we crow to chickens. And since he did not need to do [this in practice], but he asked him as if he had to do [it] - "my mother and father said" - [Rabbi Yehoshua] answered him with a jocular expression.
text.60_Daf, 6_Line, 0_Comment: They returned and conceded about the first statements: All the more so is one obligated in His honor. For, like his father and his mother, He too is a partner in one's creation; and his life and death are given over to His hands.
text.60_Daf, 6_Line, 1_Comment: "The beginning of Your word is truth": Scripture was not required to say, "The beginning of Your word is truth," except because they were speaking ill about His first statements, saying He is warning about His [own] honor; but afterwards when they heard the end of His words, they returned and conceded - they learned that the beginning of His words were true.
text.60_Daf, 7_Line, 0_Comment: For six hundred thousand profit: He would have made a profit of six hundred thousand gold dinars.
text.60_Daf, 7_Line, 1_Comment: Under his father’s head: And he was sleeping.
text.60_Daf, 10_Line, 0_Comment: And if this is [related about] one who is not commanded, and he performs it: [That] the Holy One, blessed be He, paid him his reward.
text.60_Daf, 12_Line, 0_Comment: Once he was wearing: Dama ben Netina.
text.60_Daf, 12_Line, 1_Comment: A sirkon: A cloak called a cendre (cender - a type of silk).
text.60_Daf, 13_Line, 0_Comment: Pheasant: A prized and fatty bird. A type of quail (slav) that fell in the wilderness.
text.60_Daf, 13_Line, 1_Comment: Causes him to be removed from the world: As he will be punished about him, since he showed him stinginess about his meal.
text.60_Daf, 13_Line, 2_Comment: And there is [one] who makes him grind with a millstone: Which is hard work.
text.61_Daf, 0_Line, 0_Comment: And brings him to the World-to-Come: As he honors him by speaking good and consoling words to him, and he imposes the work upon him with a soft expression. He shows him the imminent need, that they are only able to be sustained by this strain. And the text in the Yerushalmi Gemara (Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:7:10) has a story about both of them: The story of the one who feeds his father pheasant is [that] one day, his father said to him, "From where do you get all these?" He said to him, "Old man, what do you care, grind and eat" - meaning, chew and eat! He showed him that it was difficult for him. And also a story about the one who grinds with a millstone [is that] he had an old father and the king sent a requisition for his father for the king's work. His son said to him, "Father, grind; and I will go in your place to the king's work which has no limit."
text.61_Daf, 1_Line, 0_Comment: Avimi had five ordained sons during his father’s lifetime: But even so, when Rabbi Abbahu called at the gate, Avimi would run and open [it] for him and he would not let one of his sons go [do it].
text.61_Daf, 1_Line, 1_Comment: Yes, yes: I will open [it], I will open [it].
text.61_Daf, 2_Line, 0_Comment: It aided him: While he was still bent before him; such that he understood one of the psalms in the book of Psalms that he had not understood [how] to expound beforehand. And some explain that he only expounded this one verse (Psalm 79:1): "A Song of Asaph, God, the nations invaded your inheritance" - It should have stated, "A Lament of Asaph." And he expounded thus - that Asaph said a song that the Holy One, blessed be He, consumed His anger on wood and stone that was in His house; and because of this, exonerated the survivors in Israel. For were it not for this, Israel (lit. the enemies of Israel) would not have left any survivors. And this is what it says, (Lamentations 4:11) "The Lord has spent His fury, He has poured out His fierce anger, and He has kindled a fire in Zion."
text.61_Daf, 3_Line, 0_Comment: [Regarding one] such as I: Since I am beloved to my father and precious to my mother - so they do this from me - what should I do?
text.61_Daf, 3_Line, 1_Comment: Since he is a Torah scholar he will be disheartened: If you accept service from him.
text.61_Daf, 5_Line, 0_Comment: Fortunate is one who never saw them: As it is impossible to fulfill [the stipulations of] their honor as fully required. So he is punished over them.
text.61_Daf, 7_Line, 0_Comment: You are determined to leave:He reasoned that he intended to go back to his place, to Babylonia.
text.61_Daf, 7_Line, 1_Comment: Return you in peace: To your place.
text.61_Daf, 8_Line, 0_Comment: He said to him: Rav Asi [said] to Rabbi Elazar, "Perhaps, God forbid, Rabbi Yochanan is angry with me."
text.61_Daf, 9_Line, 0_Comment: One who goes to a place on the command of his father: If he knows about the people of the place, that they give honor to his father - to accept words that he would say in his name - he should not attach the honor to himself. And he should attach the honor to his father, even if he knows that they would honor him the same as his father.
text.61_Daf, 9_Line, 1_Comment: Send me on Father’s behalf: As he needs me. But if the word of his father is not listened to like his own word in a place, he should not attach [it] to his father. For then it is [only] a disgrace.
text.61_Daf, 10_Line, 0_Comment: May I be an atonement for his resting: All the bad which is supposed to come upon his soul should come upon me.
text.61_Daf, 10_Line, 1_Comment: From then onward: He already received what he [needed to] receive. For the judgment of the wicked among Israel in Geihinnom is only twelve months.
text.61_Daf, 11_Line, 0_Comment: A Sage changes the name of his father, etc.: A Sage, who expounds a teaching in public and whispers [it] to the disseminator who orates [it], changes the name of his father and the name of his teacher. If he is coming to say a matter of law that his father or his teacher said, he whispers to the disseminator, "This is what my father, my teacher said; this is what my master, my teacher said."
text.61_Daf, 11_Line, 1_Comment: But the disseminator: The one who orates it to the public does not change [the name], but rather calls him by his name and says, "This is what x said."
text.61_Daf, 11_Line, 2_Comment: Whose father: Does the disseminator not change.
text.61_Daf, 11_Line, 3_Comment: If we say the father of the disseminator: If the Sage whispers a matter of law in the name of the father of the disseminator to orate [it] to the public in the name of the one that said it, he would not change [it]; to say, "This is what my father, my teacher said." Rather he would call him by his name.
text.61_Daf, 11_Line, 4_Comment: Is that to say the disseminator is not obligated: [Is] he [not obligated] to honor his father.
text.61_Daf, 12_Line, 0_Comment: When he would teach at his regular lecture: And whisper a matter of law to the disseminator in the name of Rav Ashi, his father - he would say to the disseminator, "This is what my father, my teacher said."
text.61_Daf, 12_Line, 1_Comment: And his disseminator: When he orates [it] to the public in the name of the one that said it, he says, "This is what Rav Ashi said." And he does not say, "This is what the father and the master of the Sage said.'
text.61_Daf, 13_Line, 0_Comment: One may not stand in his place: In the place designated for his father to stand there, in the council of elders with his colleagues, for counsel.
text.61_Daf, 13_Line, 1_Comment: And he may not choose sides (lit., determine it): If his father and another Sage were disagreeing about a matter of law, he may not say, "The words of x appear [correct]."
text.62_Daf, 0_Line, 0_Comment: From whose: Does he give him food and does he give him drink.
text.62_Daf, 1_Line, 0_Comment: What difference does it make to him (lit. what comes out from him): What loss of money is there [for] him.
text.62_Daf, 2_Line, 0_Comment: They may redeem the second tithe for each other: If his father has second tithe, the son may redeem it with his [money] for what his father needs, without [the extra fee of] a fifth. And we do not say, behold he is like [the father] himself: As surely he loves him and his sustenance is upon him, so he is not a different [person] concerning him; and behold it is like someone who redeems it himself.
text.62_Daf, 2_Line, 1_Comment: And they may feed each other poor man’s tithe: If the son has poor man's tithe to distribute to the poor, he may feed it to his father if his father is poor. And likewise, all of them. And if he did not have have this tithe in his hands, he must give him nourishment from his [funds].
text.62_Daf, 3_Line, 0_Comment: For the surplus: It is impingent upon him to give food to him and to give drink to him on a middling level. But if his father requires more of a meal, he may feed him from poor man's tithe.
text.62_Daf, 5_Line, 0_Comment: That he takes a purse, etc.: And if you say the honor of the father that is upon the child [that involves] monetary loss is only [taken] from the father - if so, that purse that Rabbi Eliezer spoke about is the father's. So what difference is there to the son, [that he would] embarrass him?
text.62_Daf, 6_Line, 0_Comment: But perhaps he would become angry: And he would have said something to his father in anger.
text.62_Daf, 6_Line, 1_Comment: And he would have violated: Rav Huna.
text.62_Daf, 6_Line, 2_Comment: On account of, "before the blind": Such that he would cause his son to sin.
text.62_Daf, 7_Line, 0_Comment: At the seam: In the place of the stitch, such that he would not lose [any] of his money with this; such as at the hem.
text.62_Daf, 8_Line, 0_Comment: Those to be burned [became mixed in] among those to be stoned: It is implied that one [person] who was to be burned was mixed in with many to be stoned. And we have established it (Sanhedrin 79b) [that] all those liable for death penalties in the Torah that became mixed up - and it is not known which of them are with the lighter [punishment] and which with the stringent - are all sentenced to the lighter. For you are not permitted to move over the light to a stringent punishment for which one has not become liable.
text.62_Daf, 8_Line, 1_Comment: Rabbi Shimon says, "They are judged with stoning": As it is lighter, for Rabbi Shimon [holds that] burning is more stringent than stoning. And the reason is explained in Sanhedrin (50a).
text.62_Daf, 9_Line, 0_Comment: He said to him: Rav Yehudah, his son, [said] to Rav Yechezkel, "Father, do not teach it this way, 'Those to be burned [became mixed in] among those to be stoned'" - and the ones to be stoned would be the majority. As, if so, why did you attach the reason - that burning is more stringent. I will teach it, because it cannot be said that they would all be with burning. For if so, you have gone after the minority.
text.62_Daf, 9_Line, 1_Comment: Those to be stoned [became mixed in] among those to be burned: As even though those to be burnt are the majority, they are judged with stoning, since it is lighter.
text.62_Daf, 11_Line, 0_Comment: There it is the Rabbis who are saying to Rabbi Shimon, etc.: That which they said that stoning is more stringent is not that they are giving a reason for their words. Rather they are saying that they be judged with burning, following the majority. And that which you said [that] they should be judged with stoning to be more lenient upon them - you are not being more lenient but more stringent, since stoning is more stringent.
text.62_Daf, 12_Line, 0_Comment: Do not speak to your father like that: To suddenly inform him that he is mistaken; that you said to him, "Do not teach it this way,"
text.62_Daf, 12_Line, 1_Comment: This is what is written in the Torah? He will cause him suffering: And behold, it is as if he is saying to him, "You have transgressed the words of the Torah."
text.62_Daf, 12_Line, 2_Comment: This verse is written in the Torah: And he says to him the verse as it is written; and [the father] will understand by himself that he erred.
text.62_Daf, 13_Line, 0_Comment: [If my] father says, "Give me water": And there is another mitzvah before me to do, such as to bury the dead or a funeral.
text.63_Daf, 0_Line, 0_Comment: Here, is it his Torah: It is in wonderment (given that the Aramaic phrase can also be read as a statement): The honor is dependent on the Torah, and he cannot forgo the honor of the Torah, since it belongs to the Holy One, blessed be He!
text.63_Daf, 0_Line, 1_Comment: "And in his Torah he meditates": "But his delight is in the Torah of the Lord, and in his Torah he meditates" (Psalms 1:2). At first, it is called the Torah of God; but from when he studies it and reviews it, it is called his Torah.
text.80_Daf, 2_Line, 0_Comment: The gemoro will learn it out [from verses].
text.80_Daf, 2_Line, 1_Comment: All the more so when she is a minor if she accepted her betrothal she is betrothed. That that it taught:"youth" [is just] to let us know that preferably a minor should not be betrothed as it is explained in the gemoro.
text.140_Daf, 11_Line, 2_Comment: "Conceal it in the melody" - while those who were not aware of it and would say the blessing with the four-letter name would draw out the melody, the other Cohanim would quickly say the twelve-letter name, and it would not be heard by the public due to the voices of the others. The Hebrew word 'neima' is equivalent to the sweet voice known [in Provencal] as 'trobar'.
text.162_Daf, 7_Line, 7_Comment: 'The best of doctors is to gehenna' - They do not fear disease. They eat the food of the healthy, and they do not act humbly before God. Sometimes they kill, and sometimes they are able to heal a poor person but do not do so.
